info.game_comments: 2005 Ultimate Tournament of Champions Round 5, game 1.

(1, 1).clue: As co-editor of the influential magazine The Smart Set, this Baltimorean attacked the "booboisie"

(2, 1).clue: As "The Absent-Minded Professor", Fred MacMurray reached new heights after discovering this magical substance

(3, 1).clue: Among his 355 patents is an 1887 one for ballistite, or smokeless powder

(4, 1).clue: Continent where you'd find the shrews Crocidura nigeriae & Crocidura tansaniana

(5, 1).clue: In 2004 he replaced George Tenet as the permanent head of the CIA

(6, 1).clue: A rapid chaotic beating of the heart muscles in a nonsynchronous way

(1, 2).clue: His first U.S. publication, in the May 1915 Smart Set, was 2 stories about Dubliners

(2, 2).clue: Since 1963 this British title character has traveled through time & space in a device called the TARDIS

(3, 2).clue: In 1884 Ottmar Mergenthaler invented this machine that eliminated setting type by hand

(4, 2).clue: Canadian province where you'll most likely spot Trowbridge's shrew, which enjoys Douglas fir seeds

(5, 2).clue: The name of this intelligence service established in 1951 is from the Hebrew for "institution"

(1, 3).clue: In 1919 The Smart Set ran his first paid story, "Babes in the Woods"; in 1922, the classic "The Diamond as Big as the Ritz"

(2, 3).clue: In the '60s he played Egghead, a super-smart villain on TV's "Batman"

(3, 3).clue: The difference engine, a computing device he designed in the 1820s, was built in 1991 from his plans & it worked!

(4, 3).clue: The Southeastern shrew inhabits the marshy U.S. region that got this uninviting name from Col. William Byrd

(5, 3).clue: John Thurloe was this English leader's intelligence chief in the 1650s, gathering info on royalist plots

(6, 3).clue: A crude cart used to carry the condemned to the guillotine during the French Revolution

(1, 4).clue: This ex-sailor published 3 early sea plays in the magazine, including "The Long Voyage Home"

(2, 4).clue: The head of the house on this sitcom was alien egghead/physics professor Dick Solomon

(3, 4).clue: In 1837 Brits Cooke & Wheatstone designed an electric one; later that year, an American painter perfected it

(4, 4).clue: The Mt. Malindang shrew & the Palawan tree shrew are native to this country

(5, 4).clue: During World War II Gen. Bill Donovan ran this forerunner of the CIA

(6, 4).clue: Miles Franklin was only a teenager when she penned this bestseller about growing up in Australia's outback

(1, 5).clue: His 1st published story, "The Parthian Shot", ran in The Smart Set in 1922, before he began doing his spadework

(2, 5).clue: In this screwball comedy, stuffy paleontologist Cary Grant had a few bones to pick with Katharine Hepburn

(3, 5).clue: Named for its American inventor, this electrostatic generator is used to accelerate particles

(4, 5).clue: It would be "serendip"itous to see a Kelaart's long-clawed shrew, as it lives only on this island

(5, 5).clue: Sanskrit for "learned man", this term was used for natives recruited into intelligence gathering in British India

(6, 5).clue: 12-letter word for an oily men's hair cream to keep hair in place & make it look glossy

(1, 1).clue: We're not lyin', most of the Book of Daniel takes place in this ancient kingdom

(2, 1).clue: Jean Renoir's film "The River" was shot on location in India along the banks of this river

(4, 1).clue: Known as "The Hawk", this Chicago Cub was the 1987 National League MVP

(5, 1).clue: His empire collapsed after he died of a fever in 323 B.C.; guess he forgot to feed a cold

(6, 1).clue: On the body of water near Duluth, a place of justice employs this person for amusement

(1, 2).clue: On Purim it's a tradition to read from this Bible book with a woman's name

(2, 2).clue: The name of this Pennsylvania river is from the Dutch for "hidden channel"

(4, 2).clue: This French Minister of War lent his name to an ineffective fortification on the border with Germany

(5, 2).clue: In the Americas the 1521 conquest of this people was aided by their lack of resistance to measles & smallpox

(6, 2).clue: '60s dance craze in which you shout, "The sky is falling--at least Polaris' star group is!"

(1, 3).clue: Abigail got this king to spare her husband Nabal's life; about 10 days later Nabal died & she wed the king

(2, 3).clue: Rising in the Cottian Alps, it's the longest river in Italy

(4, 3).clue: We hope to guide you to the name of this man who developed detachable tires with his brother Edouard

(5, 3).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew stands before a portrait of George Marshall in the Pentagon in Arlington, Virginia.)  George Marshall became Chief of Staff of a 200,000 man army on this date, when WWII began; by war's end, the number was 8 million

(6, 3).clue: This place of pirates & Lost Boys adds Alaska's nickname & is home to the leader of jazz' Solar Arkestra
(6, 3).correct response: the Never Never Land of the Midnight Sun Ra

(1, 4).clue: Jacob was shocked when he lifted the veil on his first bride & found her to be this woman
